title: Psalms Chapter 55 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Psalms chapter 55 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Psalms Chapter 55 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Psalms Chapter 55.

questions.question: Who is the author of Psalm 55 according to the chapter text?
questions.explanation: Psalm 55 is titled 'A Psalm of David,' indicating David as the author (Psalms 55:1).

questions.question: What does the Psalmist ask God to do with their prayer in Psalms 55:1?
questions.explanation: The Psalmist requests God not to hide Himself from their supplication (Psalms 55:1).

questions.question: What causes the Psalmist to mourn and make a noise in Psalms 55:2?
questions.explanation: The Psalmist mourns in his complaint and makes a noise because of it (Psalms 55:2).

questions.question: According to Psalms 55:3, what do the wicked do to the Psalmist?
options: Cast iniquity upon him and hate him in wrath
questions.correctAnswer: Cast iniquity upon him and hate him in wrath
questions.explanation: The wicked cast iniquity upon the Psalmist and hate him in wrath (Psalms 55:3).

questions.question: What feeling overwhelmed the Psalmist according to Psalms 55:5?
questions.explanation: Fearfulness, trembling, and horror overwhelmed the Psalmist (Psalms 55:5).

questions.question: What does the Psalmist wish he had like a dove in Psalms 55:6?
questions.explanation: The Psalmist expresses a desire to have wings like a dove to fly away and be at rest (Psalms 55:6).

questions.question: Where does the Psalmist say he would wander if he had wings, according to Psalms 55:7?
questions.explanation: He says he would wander far off and remain in the wilderness (Psalms 55:7).

questions.question: What does the Psalmist ask God to do to the tongues of his enemies in Psalms 55:9?
questions.explanation: He asks God to destroy and divide their tongues because of violence and strife (Psalms 55:9).

questions.question: According to Psalms 55:12, who reproached the Psalmist?
questions.explanation: It was not an enemy, but a man equal to the Psalmist who reproached him (Psalms 55:12-13).

questions.question: What kind of counsel did the Psalmist share with his acquaintance in Psalms 55:14?
questions.explanation: They took sweet counsel together and walked to the house of God in company (Psalms 55:14).

questions.question: True or False: According to Psalms 55:16, the Psalmist will call upon God and the LORD shall save him.
questions.explanation: The Psalmist declares he will call upon God and the LORD will save him (Psalms 55:16).

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 55:20 states that the man put forth his hands against enemies and kept his covenant.
questions.explanation: The man put forth his hands against those at peace with him and broke his covenant (Psalms 55:20).

questions.question: True or False: According to Psalms 55:22, the LORD will never suffer the righteous to be moved.
questions.explanation: The Psalmist says to cast your burden upon the LORD, who will sustain you and not allow the righteous to be moved (Psalms 55:22).

questions.question: Complete this verse from Psalms 55:21: 'The words of his mouth were smoother than ______, but war was in his heart.'
questions.explanation: The verse states the words of his mouth were smoother than butter, yet war was in his heart (Psalms 55:21).

questions.question: Complete this verse from Psalms 55:23: 'But thou, O God, shalt bring them down into the pit of _______, bloody and deceitful men shall not live out half their days.'
questions.explanation: The Psalmist declares God will bring the wicked down into the pit of destruction (Psalms 55:23).

medium.title: Psalms Chapter 55 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Psalms Chapter 55 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with fear and anxiety. Based on Psalms 55, what biblical truth would you share about trusting God during trials?
options: Cast your burden upon the LORD, and He shall sustain you
Avoid prayer and rely on your own strength
Ignore your fears and pretend everything is fine
Do not seek God because He will not help
questions.correctAnswer: Cast your burden upon the LORD, and He shall sustain you
questions.explanation: Psalms 55:22 encourages believers to cast their burdens on the LORD, promising that He will sustain them and not allow the righteous to be moved. This teaching is reinforced by verses 16-18 where David calls on God for help and finds peace.

questions.question: How does Psalms 55 teach us about dealing with betrayal within close relationships?
options: It is more painful when a trusted friend betrays you
Only enemies can hurt you deeply
Betrayal should be ignored without prayer
Forgiveness is unnecessary for close friends
questions.correctAnswer: It is more painful when a trusted friend betrays you
questions.explanation: Psalms 55:12-14 express the pain David feels because the one who wronged him was not an enemy but a close friend and companion with whom he shared sweet fellowship and walked to the house of God.

questions.question: According to Psalms 55, what is a proper spiritual discipline to maintain during hardship?
options: Pray evening, morning, and at noon, crying aloud to God
Avoid prayer and focus solely on human solutions
Only pray when you feel like it
questions.correctAnswer: Pray evening, morning, and at noon, crying aloud to God
questions.explanation: Psalms 55:17 shows David's commitment to persistent prayer throughout the day during his trial, demonstrating the importance of consistent communication with God in times of trouble.

questions.question: A believer is overwhelmed by evil and violence in their community. Based on Psalms 55, what should their attitude be?
options: Trust God to bring justice and punish the wicked
Take revenge immediately by their own hands
Ignore the evil and pretend it does not exist
Join in the violence to protect themselves
questions.correctAnswer: Trust God to bring justice and punish the wicked
questions.explanation: Psalms 55:9-11 and 23 show David asking God to destroy the tongues that cause strife and bring down deceitful men, trusting God to execute justice rather than taking matters into their own hands.

questions.question: What does Psalms 55 teach about seeking refuge and rest during emotional distress?
options: Desiring to fly away like a dove to find rest is a natural response to pain
One should isolate permanently and reject all fellowship
Suppress all feelings and refuse to acknowledge distress
Rely solely on worldly comforts for peace
questions.correctAnswer: Desiring to fly away like a dove to find rest is a natural response to pain
questions.explanation: Psalms 55:6-8 express the Psalmist’s heartfelt wish to escape his troubles and find rest, showing that longing for peace is natural but should be accompanied by prayer and trust in God.

questions.question: How does Psalms 55 encourage believers to respond to enemies who speak smooth words but harbor evil intentions?
options: Recognize that their words can be deceiving and trust God for protection
Seek revenge using similar deceitful tactics
Ignore the danger and continue as usual
questions.correctAnswer: Recognize that their words can be deceiving and trust God for protection
questions.explanation: Psalms 55:21 warns that smooth words may hide war in the heart, and the Psalmist calls on God to protect him, teaching vigilance and reliance on God rather than trusting deceptive speech.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 55 teaches that God will never allow the righteous to be shaken or moved.
questions.explanation: Psalms 55:22 specifically states that God will sustain the righteous and never allow them to be moved, highlighting the assurance of divine support in trials.

questions.question: How does Psalms 55 instruct believers to handle the pain caused by violence and oppression?
options: Call upon God for help and trust Him to save
Retaliate with violence to defend yourself
Withdraw completely from community and prayer
questions.correctAnswer: Call upon God for help and trust Him to save
questions.explanation: Psalms 55:1-3 and verse 16 show David mourning and calling upon God to hear his prayer, believing that the LORD will save him from oppression and enemies.

questions.question: A believer is struggling with broken fellowship. Based on Psalms 55, what biblical principle can help them persevere?
options: Continue to pray and trust God to deliver you from betrayal
Give up on fellowship and live in isolation
Seek revenge against those who hurt you
questions.correctAnswer: Continue to pray and trust God to deliver you from betrayal
questions.explanation: Psalms 55:16-18 illustrates David’s reliance on God through prayer despite betrayal, emphasizing perseverance in faith rather than bitterness or isolation.

questions.question: True or False: According to Psalms 55, violence and strife are common in the city, and deceit does not depart from its streets.
questions.explanation: Psalms 55:9-11 describe the city as filled with violence, strife, deceit, and guile, showing the reality of wickedness in society that believers must navigate with God’s help.

questions.question: Based on Psalms 55, what is the attitude toward prayer when facing multiple adversaries?
options: Persist in prayer because God hears even amidst many foes
Stop praying because God is silent
Pray only once and then give up
Rely on others to pray for you but do not pray yourself
questions.correctAnswer: Persist in prayer because God hears even amidst many foes
questions.explanation: Psalms 55:17-18 show David praying persistently at various times of day and trusting that God hears him and delivers him from many enemies.

questions.question: How does Psalms 55 encourage believers to respond to those who break covenants and betray peace?
options: Trust God to bring them down into destruction
Ignore their actions and continue trusting blindly
questions.correctAnswer: Trust God to bring them down into destruction
questions.explanation: Psalms 55:20 and 23 show that God notices those who break covenants and act deceitfully, and He will bring justice upon them, teaching believers to rely on God’s judgment.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Psalms 55:6 expresses a desire to have wings like a _____ to fly away and be at rest.
questions.explanation: Psalms 55:6 says, 'Oh that I had wings like a dove! for then would I fly away, and be at rest,' showing the Psalmist’s longing for peace and escape from his troubles.

questions.question: What does Psalms 55 say about the words of a deceitful person?
options: Their words are smoother than butter but war is in their heart
Their words are always truthful and kind
Their words are harsh and openly hostile
Their words bring peace and reconciliation
questions.correctAnswer: Their words are smoother than butter but war is in their heart
questions.explanation: Psalms 55:21 describes deceitful speech as smooth and soft but hiding conflict and danger, warning believers to be discerning.

questions.question: How does Psalms 55 demonstrate the importance of fellowship in the life of faith?
options: Sweet counsel and walking together to the house of God build trust and spiritual strength
Fellowship is unnecessary and can be harmful
Only solitary prayer is acceptable before God
Avoid all social interactions to maintain purity
questions.correctAnswer: Sweet counsel and walking together to the house of God build trust and spiritual strength
questions.explanation: Psalms 55:14 reflects on the value of shared counsel and fellowship in the community of faith, showing its importance even when betrayal occurs.

hard.title: Psalms Chapter 55 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Psalms Chapter 55.

questions.question: In Psalms 55:6, the psalmist expresses a desire for wings like which bird, symbolizing escape and rest?
questions.explanation: The psalmist explicitly says, "Oh that I had wings like a dove!" indicating a wish to fly away and find rest, symbolizing peace and deliverance (Psalms 55:6).

questions.question: What literary device is predominantly used in Psalms 55:4-5 when describing the psalmist's emotional and fearful state?
questions.explanation: These verses use parallelism, a common Hebrew poetic device, to emphasize the psalmist's inner pain and fear: "My heart is sore pained... Fearfulness and trembling... horror hath overwhelmed me" (Psalms 55:4-5).

questions.question: Psalms 55:12-14 describes the betrayal by a close associate. Which New Testament figure is often associated typologically with this betrayal theme?
questions.explanation: The betrayal by a trusted companion in these verses (Psalms 55:12-14) foreshadows Judas Iscariot's betrayal of Jesus, a key typological connection in Scripture.

questions.question: In Psalms 55:21, the phrase "The words of his mouth were smoother than butter" most closely illustrates which Hebrew literary device?
questions.explanation: The phrase uses metaphor to contrast outward smooth speech with inward hostility, a device highlighting deceptive speech (Psalms 55:21).

questions.question: What is the primary theme developed in Psalms 55:22, which is echoed throughout the Psalter and New Testament teachings?
options: Trust and casting burdens on God
questions.correctAnswer: Trust and casting burdens on God
questions.explanation: The verse encourages believers to cast their burdens on the LORD, emphasizing trust in God's sustaining power, a recurring biblical theme (Psalms 55:22).

questions.question: According to Psalms 55:9-11, what social condition is the psalmist lamenting within the city?
questions.explanation: The psalmist describes violence, strife, wickedness, deceit, and guile as pervasive in the city, reflecting social corruption (Psalms 55:9-11).

questions.question: Psalms 55:16-17 shows the psalmist committing to prayer at which times of the day?
questions.explanation: The psalmist states a commitment to pray "Evening, and morning, and at noon," showing persistent devotion (Psalms 55:17).

questions.question: The Hebrew word translated as 'maschil' in Psalms 55:1 is best understood as indicating what kind of psalm?
questions.explanation: "Maschil" implies a teaching or meditation psalm designed to impart wisdom or insight (Psalms 55:1).

questions.question: Which ancient Near Eastern cultural practice is reflected in Psalms 55:20's reference to "breaking his covenant"?
questions.explanation: Breaking a covenant recalls treaty violations common in the ancient Near East, where loyalty and oaths were central, as lamented in this verse (Psalms 55:20).

questions.question: True or False: In Psalms 55, the psalmist asks God to divide the tongues of his enemies as a plea for peace in the city.
questions.explanation: Psalms 55:9 explicitly requests God to "destroy and divide their tongues" due to the violence and strife in the city, indicating a plea for peace.

questions.question: The phrase "Let death seize upon them" in Psalms 55:15 is an example of what kind of biblical theme?
questions.explanation: "Let death seize upon them" expresses an imprecatory prayer, a common biblical theme where the psalmist calls for God's judgment on the wicked (Psalms 55:15).

questions.question: How does Psalms 55:18 illustrate the theme of divine deliverance amidst overwhelming opposition?
options: God delivers the soul in peace from many enemies
questions.correctAnswer: God delivers the soul in peace from many enemies
questions.explanation: This verse states God delivered the psalmist's soul in peace despite many adversaries, highlighting divine protection (Psalms 55:18).

questions.question: What does the psalmist identify as the cause of his suffering in Psalms 55:3?
options: Voice of the enemy and oppression of the wicked
questions.correctAnswer: Voice of the enemy and oppression of the wicked
questions.explanation: The psalmist laments because of the voice of enemies and oppression by the wicked who cast iniquity and hate him (Psalms 55:3).

questions.question: Which Psalm verse describes the psalmist's companions as 'a man mine equal, my guide, and mine acquaintance' and what does this imply about the betrayal?
options: Psalms 55:13 - Betrayal from a close friend
questions.correctAnswer: Psalms 55:13 - Betrayal from a close friend
questions.explanation: The verse identifies the betrayer as a close equal and companion, intensifying the sense of personal betrayal (Psalms 55:13).

questions.question: The repeated pleas for God to act against the wicked in Psalms 55 reflect which broader biblical motif?
questions.explanation: The psalm repeatedly calls for God to judge and punish the wicked, reflecting the biblical motif of divine justice (Psalms 55:9, 15, 23).

theological.title: Psalms Chapter 55 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Psalms Chapter 55 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What is the Psalmist's initial plea to God in Psalms 55:1?
options: Give ear to my prayer and do not hide from my supplication
Grant me wings like a dove
Destroy the wicked in the city
questions.correctAnswer: Give ear to my prayer and do not hide from my supplication
questions.explanation: In Psalms 55:1, the Psalmist asks God to listen carefully to his prayer and not to hide from his requests. This highlights God's attribute of attentiveness to human prayers, consistent with 1 John 5:14, Jeremiah 29:12, Psalm 34:17, and Hebrews 4:16.

questions.question: According to Psalms 55:6, what does the Psalmist desire to have like a dove?
options: Wings to fly away and be at rest
A shield to protect from enemies
questions.correctAnswer: Wings to fly away and be at rest
questions.explanation: The Psalmist expresses a deep desire for escape from turmoil by wishing for wings like a dove to fly away and find rest (Psalms 55:6). This metaphor reflects the human longing for peace, paralleling Isaiah 40:31, Matthew 10:16, and Revelation 12:14 which use dove imagery for divine protection and peace.

questions.question: In Psalms 55:9, what does the Psalmist ask God to do to the tongues of the wicked?
questions.explanation: The Psalmist asks God to 'destroy and divide their tongues' because of the violence and strife seen in the city (Psalms 55:9). This reflects a plea for divine justice against deceit and slander, echoing themes in Proverbs 6:16-19, James 3:5-6, Psalm 12:3, and Romans 3:13.

questions.question: Who does the Psalmist identify as the one who has reproached and magnified himself against him in Psalms 55:12-13?
options: A man equal to the Psalmist, his guide and acquaintance
An enemy from a foreign land
questions.correctAnswer: A man equal to the Psalmist, his guide and acquaintance
questions.explanation: The Psalmist highlights that the offender was not a foreign enemy but 'a man mine equal, my guide, and mine acquaintance' (Psalms 55:12-13). This betrayal by a close companion touches on human sinfulness and broken fellowship, consistent with Judas’ betrayal (John 13:18), Cain and Abel (Genesis 4:8), and Peter's denial (Luke 22:54-62).

questions.question: What does the Psalmist pray for concerning those who dwell in wickedness in Psalms 55:15?
options: Let death seize upon them and let them go down quick into hell
That they might repent and find mercy
That they be cast out from the city
That God would give them peace and understanding
questions.correctAnswer: Let death seize upon them and let them go down quick into hell
questions.explanation: In Psalms 55:15, the Psalmist petitions for swift judgment upon the wicked who dwell among them. This plea for divine justice parallels Romans 1:18, Proverbs 11:31, Revelation 20:14, and Psalm 1:6 which affirm God's righteous judgment on the wicked.

questions.question: How often does the Psalmist declare he will pray and cry aloud according to Psalms 55:17?
questions.explanation: The Psalmist commits to praying three times a day—'evening, and morning, and at noon' (Psalms 55:17). This reflects a disciplined prayer life seen in Daniel 6:10, Acts 3:1, and Psalm 119:164 emphasizing continual communion with God.

questions.question: What assurance does the Psalmist give about God's response to his prayers in Psalms 55:16?
questions.explanation: The Psalmist confidently declares that God will save him when he calls upon Him (Psalms 55:16). This assurance of salvation aligns with Psalm 34:17, Isaiah 12:2, Romans 10:13, and 2 Corinthians 1:10 which emphasize God's saving power.

questions.question: What does the Psalmist say about the words of his betrayer in Psalms 55:21?
options: His words were smoother than butter but war was in his heart
His words were harsh and condemning
He spoke with honest and faithful lips
His speech was full of blessings
questions.correctAnswer: His words were smoother than butter but war was in his heart
questions.explanation: Psalms 55:21 describes the betrayer’s duplicity: 'The words of his mouth were smoother than butter, but war was in his heart.' This theme of deceitful speech is echoed in Proverbs 26:24-28, Matthew 26:48-50, Jeremiah 9:8, and Romans 16:18.

questions.question: What does the Psalmist urge believers to do with their burdens according to Psalms 55:22?
options: Cast them upon the LORD, who will sustain them
Share them only with close friends
Ignore them and focus on joy
questions.correctAnswer: Cast them upon the LORD, who will sustain them
questions.explanation: Psalms 55:22 encourages believers to cast their burdens on the LORD, promising that He will sustain them and not allow the righteous to be moved. This teaching is consistent with Matthew 11:28-30, 1 Peter 5:7, Psalm 46:1, and Isaiah 41:10.

questions.question: What does the Psalmist say about the longevity of deceitful and bloody men in Psalms 55:23?
options: They shall not live out half their days
They will prosper for many years
questions.correctAnswer: They shall not live out half their days
questions.explanation: In Psalms 55:23, the Psalmist proclaims that deceitful and bloody men will have shortened lives, a reflection of divine judgment. This is consistent with Proverbs 10:27, Psalm 37:10, Job 20:29, and Ecclesiastes 8:13 on the fate of the wicked.

questions.question: What emotional states does the Psalmist describe experiencing in Psalms 55:4-5?
options: Sore pain, fearfulness, trembling, and horror
questions.correctAnswer: Sore pain, fearfulness, trembling, and horror
questions.explanation: The Psalmist describes deep inner distress including sore pain, fearfulness, trembling, and horror (Psalms 55:4-5). These emotions illustrate human suffering under oppression, resonating with Psalm 6:6, Lamentations 3:19-20, Isaiah 41:10, and 2 Corinthians 1:3-7.

questions.question: What is the Psalmist's response to persistent violence and strife in the city as described in Psalms 55:10-11?
options: He acknowledges mischief, sorrow, deceit, and guile filling the city
He praises the city’s peace and righteousness
He ignores the trouble and focuses on personal prayer
He flees immediately without confronting the problem
questions.correctAnswer: He acknowledges mischief, sorrow, deceit, and guile filling the city
questions.explanation: In Psalms 55:10-11, the Psalmist describes the city as filled with constant mischief, sorrow, deceit, and guile, recognizing the pervasive sin. This echoes Jeremiah 5:1-9, Ezekiel 22:23-31, Romans 3:13-18, and 1 Corinthians 15:33 on the prevalence of sin in society.

questions.question: What does the Psalmist identify as the reason the wicked do not fear God in Psalms 55:19?
options: Because they are blinded by wealth
questions.explanation: Psalms 55:19 states that the wicked have 'no changes,' meaning they are unrepentant or uncorrected, which leads to their lack of fear of God. This relates to Proverbs 1:29-31, Romans 1:21, Hebrews 12:25, and Ezekiel 33:11 on human obstinance and divine judgment.

questions.question: How does the Psalmist describe his fellowship with the betrayer in Psalms 55:14?
options: They took sweet counsel together and walked to the house of God in company
They were often in conflict and disagreement
They never shared their thoughts openly
They were strangers to one another
questions.correctAnswer: They took sweet counsel together and walked to the house of God in company
questions.explanation: Psalms 55:14 reveals the intimacy of the relationship by describing sweet counsel and shared worship, highlighting the pain of betrayal. This parallels examples of betrayal in close fellowship such as David and Ahithophel (2 Samuel 15:12), Judas and Jesus (John 13), and Peter and Jesus (Luke 22).

questions.question: What does the Psalmist say about God's ancient nature and His hearing of the afflicted in Psalms 55:19?
options: God abides of old and will hear and afflict the wicked
God ignores the cries of the oppressed
God favors the wicked over the righteous
questions.correctAnswer: God abides of old and will hear and afflict the wicked
questions.explanation: Psalms 55:19 emphasizes God's eternal nature ('abideth of old') and His justice in hearing the righteous and afflicting the wicked. This is consistent with Isaiah 40:28, Deuteronomy 33:27, Psalm 90:2, and Revelation 1:8 regarding God's eternality and justice.
